parts.text: I want to make a "fork" of PinPoint in my github. It doesn't seem like GitHub allows me to fork my repo directly, so we'll have to do this manually. name it PinPoint-SkillEval
I will start by checking your current git remotes and the repository's visibility to ensure the new "fork" matches the original.

args.command: git remote -v && gh repo view --json isPrivate,name,owner
args.description: Checking current git remotes and repository visibility.

parts.text: I've created the repository and pushed your current branch. I'll now check your local branches to see if we should also push `main` to ensure the new repository is a complete "fork."
make sure you're pushign origin/main to it
I'll fetch the latest `main` from `origin` and push it to the `main` branch of your new `skilleval` remote.

args.description: Fetching main from origin and pushing it to the skilleval remote as main.
args.command: git fetch origin main:main && git push skilleval main:main

The repository `timothyfroehlich/PinPoint-SkillEval` is now set up with only the `main` branch.

I've also added a local remote named `skilleval` for this new repository. Would you like me to remove it, or should I keep it so you can push to both?
